title: 104_hr3683
content: The "Congressional Campaign Integrity Act" prohibits the use of labor organization dues and fees for political activities, including contributions or expenditures for Federal elections and support for political activities or organizations. Labor organizations are not allowed to use dues or fees for these purposes according to the amended Section 316 of the Federal Election Campaign Act of 1971. The Federal Election Campaign Act of 1971 prohibits candidates from making personal loans to their campaign committees or providing financial support for their campaigns. Additionally, the Act equalizes the contribution limitation for multicandidate political committees with the limitation applicable to other individuals. The Federal Election Campaign Act of 1971 is amended to increase the contribution limits for individuals and multicandidate political committees. The amendment raises the limit from $1,000 to $2,000 for individuals and from $5,000 to $2,000 for multicandidate political committees. Additionally, there is a limitation on contributions from out-of-state individuals to House of Representatives elections. Section 315 of the Federal Election Campaign Act of 1971 is amended to restrict candidates from accepting contributions from out-of-state individuals exceeding those from in-state residents. Additionally, a new section on "soft money of political parties" is added to Title III of the Act. The Federal Election Campaign Act prohibits national party committees from soliciting or receiving funds not subject to limitations. State, district, or local party committees must report any expenditures that could impact federal elections. The Federal Election Campaign Act restricts the use of funds for activities related to Federal elections, with exceptions for certain expenditures by State, district, or local party committees. The Federal Election Campaign Act limits the use of funds for Federal election activities, except for specific expenses by State, district, or local party committees, such as administrative expenses and grassroots campaign materials. The Federal Election Campaign Act restricts the use of funds for Federal election activities, allowing State, district, or local party committees to spend on administrative expenses and grassroots campaign materials that promote State or local candidates. Any funds used for these activities must comply with the Act's limitations, prohibitions, and reporting requirements. The Federal Election Campaign Act prohibits political party committees from soliciting funds for tax-exempt organizations and restricts candidates from receiving funds for non-Federal elections that exceed Federal contribution limits. The Federal Election Campaign Act prohibits candidates for Federal office from establishing or raising funds for organizations described in section 501(c) of the Internal Revenue Code if they raise funds from the public. The Federal Election Campaign Act prohibits candidates from raising funds for organizations under section 501(c) of the Internal Revenue Code if they engage in voter registration or get-out-the-vote campaigns. An individual holding a Federal office or a position in level I of the Executive Schedule is considered to hold Federal office for this purpose. SEC. 7. REPORTING REQUIREMENTS. The Federal Election Campaign Act of 1971 is amended to include new reporting requirements for political committees other than national committees of political parties. These committees must report all receipts and disbursements related to Federal elections, itemizing any amounts over $200 from a single person in a calendar year. The Federal Election Campaign Act of 1971 is amended to include new reporting requirements for State committees of political parties, allowing them to file reports under State law with the Commission if they contain the same information. Additionally, authorized committees must report all receipts and disbursements related to Federal elections, itemizing amounts over $200 from a single person in a calendar year. The Federal Election Campaign Act of 1971 is amended to include new reporting requirements for State committees of political parties, allowing them to file reports under State law with the Commission if they contain the same information. Additionally, authorized committees must report all receipts and disbursements related to Federal elections, itemizing amounts over $200 from a single person in a calendar year. The Act is further amended to specify disbursements for primary, general, and other elections in which the candidate participates, as well as changes to names and addresses reporting requirements. SEC. 8. SOFT MONEY OF PERSONS OTHER THAN POLITICAL PARTIES. Section 304 of the Federal Election Campaign Act of 1971 is amended to include new subsection (f) regarding Election Activity of Persons Other Than Political Parties. It outlines requirements for filing statements for disbursements exceeding $2,000 for certain activities. The amended Section 304 of the Federal Election Campaign Act of 1971 requires filing statements for disbursements exceeding $2,000 for certain activities, excluding candidates, authorized committees, and independent expenditures. Statements must be filed with the Commission and include information on support or opposition to candidates or political parties.
